Advantages of the use of a RMarkdown website over canvas

## It's in R
If you know R, which the people who are supposed to work on this do, it is quite easy to make simple pages with it. To make these kind of pages on canvas, you need at least some HTML knowledge. Furthermore, it can easily read and run R-code, making it very easy to include examples and it's results. Lastly, canvas is quite restricted in the use of HTML code. Here, if you have some website building experience, you can easily add cool extra features that make the R-helpdesk even better, like you see below:

## Editor
Instead of showing code staticly, you can add an editor that automatically recognizes and styles R-code while the student is edditing
```ace
ggplot(starwars, aes(x=height,y=mass)) +
  geom_point()
```

## Datacamp integration
You can even add your own datacamp excersizes. You can program when an answer is correct, add hints and all that stuff.

<script type="text/javascript" src="https://cdn.datacamp.com/dcl-react.js.gz"></script>
```{=html}
<div data-datacamp-exercise data-lang="r">
	<code data-type="pre-exercise-code">
		# This will get executed each time the exercise gets initialized
		b = 6
	</code>
	<code data-type="sample-code">
		# Create a variable a, equal to 5


		# Print out a


	</code>
	<code data-type="solution">
		# Create a variable a, equal to 5
		a <- 5

		# Print out a
		print(a)
	</code>
	<code data-type="sct">
		test_object("a")
		test_function("print")
		success_msg("Great job!")
	</code>
	<div data-type="hint">Use the assignment operator (<code><-</code>) to create the variable <code>a</code>.</div>
</div>
```
